content: From the Financial Times: quote: German stimulus cash to fund army By Chris Bryant in Berlin Published: March 2 2009 02:00 | Last updated: March 2 2009 02:00 The German government is to spend part of its €50bn economic stimulus package on supplies for its armed forces, possibly including submachineguns, military vehicles and underwater mine detectors. The revelation has upset anti-war politicians and raised questions about the effectiveness of measures intended to help Germany overcome a deep recession...

content: I think it's a very good idea, with the world situation at the moment. Every country is re-arming themselves in someway and with the soon to be caving in to Russia over the missile defense shield against Iran, I don't blame them. Od course they are wasting their money on machine-guns, vehicles and mine detectors against nuclear missles.

content: Re-equipping one's armed forces helped get out of the last depression. But then the equipment had to be used - that led to significant new expenditure on more new equipment and reconstructing all the damage that equipment cost. Waste in making so much military equipment that production has to be 'donated to the poor' is something else. It can actually 'go bad' if it's best before date is exceeded. It usually isn't worth recycling, and makes hellish land (or ocean) fill. Better to build the domestic poor a free house, provide cradle to grave medicare and educate every kid for nothing. It creates more jobs, isn't hazardous to life and it's cheaper, too.
